flawed_nl_solution:
The $15 is 1 - 1/4 = 3/4 of the money left.
Since 3/4 is equal to $15, then 1/4 is equal to $15/{fraction_of_money_left_after_spending.numerator} = $5.
So Lucy had $5 x {fraction_of_money_left_after_spending.denominator} = $<<5*{fraction_of_money_left_after_spending.denominator}=20>>20 left after losing 1/3 of her money.
Hence, $20 is 1 - 1/3 = 1/3 of the money that Lucy had at the beginning.
Since 1/3 is equal to $20, then 1/3 is equal to $20/{fraction_of_initial_money_remaining.numerator} = $20.
Therefore, Lucy had $20 x {fraction_of_initial_money_remaining.denominator} = $<<20*{fraction_of_initial_money_remaining.denominator}=60>>60 at the beginning.

error_details.explanation: The result of this computation should be 2/3, not 1/3. It appears there was an off-by-one error in the fraction.
